title-group.article-title: Generalizations of a Classical Theorem in Number Theory

abstract.p: A classical theorem conjectured by Jacobi asserts that for an odd prime $p$, the sum of the quadratic residues in the interval $(0, p)$ is less than the sum of the quadratic nonresidues if and only if $p \equiv 3 (\operatorname{mod} 4)$. We generalize Jacobi's problem to $k$th powers $(\operatorname{mod} p), k > 2$, and we consider in some detail a generalization of Jacobi's conjecture to quadratic residues and nonresidues $(\operatorname{mod} n), n$ an arbitrary integer $> 2$. From the set of least positive residues $(\operatorname{mod} n)$, let $c_0$ denote the subgroup of quadratic residues $(\operatorname{mod} n)$ and let $c_1, c_2, \ldots, c_t$ be the cosets which can be formed with respect to this subgroup. Computer data supports the following generalized Jacobi conjecture: The sum of the elements in $c_0$ is less than or equal to the sum in any of the other cosets for every integer $n > 2$, a surprising conjecture, especially in view of the fact that counterexamples are easily obtained for $k = 4, 6, 8, 10$, etc. (The coset sums are identical for odd $k$ and prime modulus.) We resolve the generalized Jacobi conjecture in the affirmative when, for example, $n$ is an integer admitting a primitive root, or $n = 2^\alpha, \alpha \geqslant 3$. (Here we give explicit formulae for the four coset sums.) For $n = 2p^\alpha$, our proof that the quadratic residues and the quadratic nonresidues $(\operatorname{mod} n)$ have the same sum for odd prime $p$ if and only if $p \not\equiv 3 (\operatorname{mod} 8)$ is purely elementary. On the other hand, we need Dirichlet's class number formula for quadratic number fields with discriminant $-p \equiv 5 (\operatorname{mod} 8)$ to show that the sum of the quadratic nonresidues strictly exceeds the sum of the quadratic residues $(\operatorname{mod} 2p^\alpha) \text{if} p \equiv 3 (\operatorname{mod} 8)$. Computer data gives rise to a host of interesting problems we are unable to resolve. For example, if $n =2p_1^{\alpha_1} p_2^{\alpha_2}\cdots p_r^{\alpha_r}, 1 \leqslant i \leqslant r$, we conjecture that we have $p_i \equiv 3 (\operatorname{mod} 8)$ for every $i$. It is not hard to show that the coset sums are identical if every $p_i \equiv 1 (\operatorname{mod} 4)$. However, the problem of finding a necessary condition is very difficult since, e.g., the coset sums are not identical for $n \leqslant 1146 \text{when} n = 2 \cdot 3 \cdot p \text{if} p \equiv 23 (\operatorname{mod} 24)$ but the sums are identical if $p \equiv 7 (\operatorname{mod} 24)$.
